subtitle: Quetzalcoatl- "Feathered Serpent" / "Precious Twin"
description:
The Feathered Serpent is one of the most important deities of ancient Mesoamerica. As god of wind, learning, and creation,
                Quetzalcoatl brought civilization to humanity - the calendar, writing, agriculture, and the arts. He represents the
                union of earth (serpent) and sky (quetzal bird), the boundary between the material and spiritual realms.

extracted_lists: Scribal devotion: Scribes honored Itzamna as the patron of their sacred art
Calendar rituals: Ceremonies marking the day Ahau and calendar transitions
Healing invocations: Prayers seeking Itzamna's blessing for medical treatments
Royal legitimation: Kings claimed descent from or connection to Itzamna

periods.description: Oldest deity concept, predating Aztecs by millennia
Associated with Ce Acatl Topiltzin, priest-king of Tula
Wind god and bringer of civilization, but not primary imperial cult

calendarAssociations.cyclicalReturn: Quetzalcoatl prophesied to return in year Ce Acatl (1 Reed)
calendarAssociations.significance: Myth of Cort√©s' arrival in 1519 (year 1 Reed cycle) created confusion

preColumbian.name: Codex Borgia (plates 49-56)
preColumbian.content: Quetzalcoatl's role in cosmic creation and wind god manifestations

preColumbian.name: Codex Telleriano-Remensis
preColumbian.content: Wind god ceremonies and agricultural associations

colonialSpanish.name: Florentine Codex (Book 1, 3)
colonialSpanish.author: Bernardino de Sahag√∫n
colonialSpanish.content: Detailed mythology of Quetzalcoatl and Toltec origins

nativeNahuatl.name: Anales de Cuauhtitl√°n
nativeNahuatl.content: Detailed Quetzalcoatl mythology and human ruler identification

nativeNahuatl.name: Sahag√∫n's Nahuatl Texts (Florentine Codex original)
nativeNahuatl.content: Direct Nahua account of Quetzalcoatl theology

primary.name: Tula (Tollan)
primary.description: Great Temple with Quetzalcoatl serpent columns (Atlantes)
primary.findings: Serpent sculptures, ritual vessels, astronomical alignments

primary.purpose: Ensure wind-driven rain cycles for agriculture

sacrificialRites.significance: Quetzalcoatl represented cultural ideal - civilization over sacrifice, though Aztecs modified this

civilizationalRole.gifts: Calendar, writing, agriculture, arts, organized society
civilizationalRole.symbol: Union of earth (serpent) and sky (quetzal bird)
civilizationalRole.cultural: Represented intellectual and artistic pursuits, counterbalance to warrior cults

_methodologyNotes: Calendar associations verified against primary codex sources
Codex sources include primary Spanish colonial records and native nahuatl/maya texts
Archaeological sites documented from excavation reports and academic publications
Sacrificial rituals documented from Florentine Codex and validated against archaeological evidence
